A Blackbox in the Car ?

American road planners are looking for a source of money to repair the crumbling highway system , and believe they have found the solution in a small black box that fits in the dashboard of every car .

The devices that record every kilometre taken and report the information to the authorities are at the heart of a controversial attempt by Washington and the state planning offices to revise the outdated system for financing US roads .
The normally rather boring area of road planning has suddenly sparked an intense debate with colorful alliances .

Libertarians have allied themselves with environmental groups , arguing that the government can use the small boxes to record the miles taken – and possibly where they were driven – and then use the information to calculate tax bills .
The Tea Party is appalled .
The American Civil Rights Association ( ACLU ) is also deeply concerned and expresses a number of data protection concerns .
But , while Congress cannot agree on an approach , several states are no longer waiting .
They are currently considering how to switch over the next ten years to a system where drivers pay per mile .
Thousands of drivers have already tested the tachographs , some of which are equipped with GPS monitoring .
This is really a must for our country .

“ It ’ s nothing we ’ re only likely to use , ” said Hasan Ikhrata , Southern California ’ s Managing Director , who plans to record the miles taken by all Californian motorists in the state from 2025 .
The way we pay these taxes will change .
The technology is there .
The initiative comes at a time when the Highway Trust Fund , financed from taxes paid to Americans at the fuel dispenser , is bankrupt .
But in America , there is no longer as much dancing as in the past .
Cars consume less petrol .
The state oil tax of 18.4 cents per gallon ( less than 4 euro cents per litre ) has not increased for 20 years .
Politicians , at high fuel prices , do not dare to raise the tax by even a penny .
“ The gas tax is simply not sustainable , ” says Lee Munnich , an expert on traffic legislation at the University of Minnesota .
His state recently equipped 500 cars with tachographs to test a mine-based payment system .
“ This is the most sensible alternative in the long term , ” he said .
Bureaucrats call it a meile-based user fee .

It is not surprising that the idea is welcomed by urban liberals , because the tax could be used , for example , to influence driving behavior in such a way that congestion and climate-damaging emissions are reduced .
Californian planners are relying on the system to develop strategies to achieve the federal state ’ s ambitious , legally established climate change goals .
But the Republican Bill Shuster of Pennsylvania , Chairman of the House Transportation Committee , has also declared that he sees it as the most viable long-term alternative .
The free marketers of the Reason Foundation are also inspired by the idea of having drivers pay back .
“ This is not a tax that disappears in a black hole , ” explains Adrian Moore , Vice President for Policy at Reason .
People pay directly for what they get .
The movement is also supported by two former American transport ministers , who , in a 2011 report , called on Congress to move in the direction of a mega-based reckoning .
The US Senate approved a $ 90 million pilot project last year , which would have included 10,000 cars .

But the majority in the House of Representatives prevented the move , responding to the concerns of rural MEPs who represent people who often have to travel many miles on their way to work or to the city in everyday life .
Yet several states and major cities are moving in this direction on their own .
Oregon is the most committed driver to the country ’ s largest experiment , currently attracting 5,000 .
These drivers will soon pay the mileage charges to the federal state instead of the mineral oil tax .
Nevada has already completed a pilot project .
New York City is also considering this .
Illinois is testing it to a limited extent with trucks .

And the I-95 coalition , which includes the transport ministries of 17 states on the east coast ( including Maryland , Pennsylvania , Virginia , and Florida ) , is exploring how to introduce the change .
The concept is not a universal hit .
In Nevada , where 50 volunteers were recently equipped with equipment , drivers were skeptical about the government ’ s ability to follow any of its movements .
“ Concerns about Big Brother and such things were a big problem , ” explains Alauddin Khan , Head of Strategy and Results Management at the Department of Transport of Nevada .
People did not want it .
When the test started , the ACLU of Nevada warned on its website : “ It would be relatively easy to turn the tachograph into full-grown monitoring devices . ”
There is no need to build a gigantic , bulky technological infrastructure that would inevitably be used to collect data about individuals ’ daily movements .
Nevada is one of a number of states that are now looking for affordable technology to enable the state to capture the miles travelled , but not exactly when and where .
So , Khan said , the public would also be more reassured .
The hunt for this technology has led some authorities to a small start-up company called True Mileage in California .
The company was not originally set up to help states tax drivers .
Rather , their aim was to take root in an emerging market for car insurance companies , where drivers are to pay on the basis of the miles they have travelled .
However , the devices they test are also interesting for road planners , because they do not work with GPS and provide only limited information that is regularly uploaded via modem .
“ People are more willing to participate when their speed and location are not recorded , ” said Ryan Morrison , CEO of True Mileage .
Major mistakes have been made in some of these public pilot programmes .
There are much cheaper and less intrusive ways of doing this .
In Oregon , planners experiment with giving drivers a range of choices .
You can choose a device with or without GPS .
Or they do not choose a unit at all and instead pay a lump-sum fee based on the average miles taken by all federal residents .
Other bodies hope to be able to sell the concept of a suspicious public by providing the equipment with more functions than with less .

In New York City , traffic officials want to develop a taxable device that can also pay parking fees , pay insurance only for miles and collect speed data from other vehicles in real time , allowing drivers to avoid congestion .
“ Drivers would be motivated to participate by the added value of the benefits offered by the system , ” says a city planning document .
However , some road planners wonder whether all the talk about paying per mile is not just a huge diversion .
Officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Commission for the San Francisco Bay area said that Congress could solve the problem of the bankrupt Highway Trust Fund simply by raising fuel tax .
An additional one-time fee or annual levy could be imposed on motorists using hybrid vehicles or other vehicles that consume little petrol , so that they also pay a fair share .
“ There is no reason for an operation if an aspirin is sufficient , ” says Randy Rentzler , the head of the Commission ’ s legislative and public affairs . , , , , , , , , , , , , ,

Esa Decides on Big Space : Missions for Billions
Distance planets , gravitational waves or black holes - European Space Agency experts now need to agree on two major projects they want to launch in the next few years .
30 suggestions were available , five are still in the race .
Worlds far away .
Astronomers have already found more than 1000 planets on other stars .
No one knows whether there is life on at least some of them .
The choice is difficult : should you search for gravitational waves ?
Or rather explore the origins of the cosmos ?
Or look for earthly planets and perhaps discover alien life ?
These are the questions that the European Space Agency , Esa , is asking itself .
For their Cosmic Vision programme , they are looking for ideas for two major space projects that are intended to significantly advance research .
The budget for such " L missions " is approximately EUR 1 billion .
The start is expected to be 2028 and 2034 .
In early September , the elite of European space research met in Paris to discuss proposals for such missions .
30 ideas were under discussion , five of which have now come to a close .
Many bodies look at the proposals and catch up with researchers .
In the next few days a final decision will be made by the scientific programme committee .
A total of four major questions have been selected by the Esa , to which the missions of the 2007 Cosmic Vision programme will find answers .
What are the conditions for the formation of planets and life ?
The exact processes of the formation of stars from large gas clouds - and thus also the formation of planets that circle these stars - are still in the proverbial dark .
A large infrared telescope in space could penetrate this darkness .
And if a star owns a planet , under what circumstances can life develop there ?
To address this issue , the Cheops space telescope will launch in 2017 , which will examine more closely 500 already known planetary systems in our vicinity .
But the possibilities are limited , Cheops is a small mission with a budget of 150 million euros .

With larger instruments , astronomers could map earthly planets and even analyze the composition of their atmospheres and thus search for " biomarkers " : gases that are considered an indication of biological activity .
How does the solar system work ?
This question , too , is ultimately intended to shed light on the conditions for the emergence of life .
The magnetic activity of a star plays an important role and the interaction of its magnetic field and the particle radiation it produces with the planet system .
In our solar system , these processes can be investigated for example .
With the Solar Orbiter , the Esa has already approved a M-class mission ( where the budget is about half a billion euros ) for this question .
The probe is scheduled to launch in 2017 and monitor the sun ’ s surface and activity closely .
Jupiter and its moons are of great interest to the researchers .
They want to find out what role the giant planet has played in the development of the solar system .
For this purpose , the Esa provides the first of the three L-missions of the Cosmic Vision programme .
The probe " Justice " ( Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer ) is expected to begin its journey in 2022 .
Eight years later , she reached Jupiter and was to investigate the atmosphere of the planet as well as the icy moons of Europe , Kallisto and Ganymed .
What are the basic physical laws of the universe ?
The universe offers many possibilities to study matter under extreme conditions and to examine whether the laws of nature known to us are still valid there .
Perhaps there are also deviations that could lead physicists to a new theory under which all known laws of nature can be united .
How did the universe come about and what does it consist of ?
13.7 billion years ago our cosmos was created by the big bang .

In addition to the familiar matter of stars , planets , and creatures like us , there is Dark Matter , whose gravity holds together galaxies and galaxy clusters , and Dark Energy , which accelerates the expansion of the universe .
So far , researchers do not know which physical laws were valid in the first fractions of the Big Bang , nor what Dark Matter and Dark Energy consist of .
With " Euclid " , the Esa has already approved an M mission , which is scheduled to start in 2020 .

With a special telescope , the probe will investigate the distribution of matter in the universe for the first time in the entire sky , thus enabling conclusions about the nature of Dark Matter and Dark Energy .
Who could Race
Of the 30 proposals , only two will remain at the end of the selection process .
In the opinion of many experts " E-Lisa " , the best chances for an L mission to be granted is an ambitious concept for detecting gravitational waves .
Physicists mean changes in the structure of space time that Albert Einstein predicted almost 100 years ago .
To this day , they have not been shown . were .
Elisa could do that , the scientists hope behind the project .
The mission provides for a detector consisting of two or three probes located in space .
In contrast to plants on Earth , it could also provide evidence of gravitational waves created during the Big Bang , providing new insights into the emergence of the cosmos .

Four more proposals are still competing for the second L-mission : a large X-ray telescope called " Athena " , which is to explore black holes among other things , " Icy Planets " , another mission to the outer planets of the solar system , " Prism " , a mission to measure the cosmic background radiation , and the " Exoplanet Finder " , which is to detect and investigate earthy planets .
Among other things , suggestions have already been made to transport samples back from Mars , to explore moon , Venus and asteroids , and to solar physics .

What happens to my email ?
Email is actually called electronic letter .
Is it technically the case that mail secrecy has been implemented in the design of the Internet service , similar to that of conventional mail ?
When designing the early Internet services , the focus was on making communication possible .
For this reason , basic technical protocols have not taken care to create a solid foundation for listening safe correspondence .
As a result , a traditional email is more like an open postcard than a sealed letter .
If the user " Anna " sends an email to " Benni " , are the computers of the two connected directly ?
Anna 's e-mail program or browser sends the mail to the mail server of your service provider .
For example , if it has a GMail account , Google would be .
This mail server sends the content to the provider Benni uses .
On the route the mail can run over a number of other servers on the Internet .
Bennie can then call the content to his provider .
Are conventional e-mails read through the network ?
Most mails are read several times by software robots on the way .
The sender 's provider usually checks whether the mail contains a malicious program as an attachment .
A virus check is also carried out on the receiver systems .
In addition , providers check whether this is an annoying and unwanted spam mail that is deleted or at least sorted away into a spam folder .
Do the robots have another task ?
For systems like GMail , the robot also determines the information Google needs to place context advertisements .
If Anna and Benni communicate via GMail about their upcoming holiday trip , Google may link to holiday offers .
Do unknown people also read the emails ?
There is a very low chance that unauthorized people will read a mail .
In theory , however , this is possible .
In companies , administrators often have the opportunity to read electronic mail .
The law enforcement authorities and secret services also have legal opportunities to intercept or take note of e-mails .
In addition , there are possible illegal spillovers .
Is it possible to protect emails from being read ?
Encryption according to the OpenPGP standard can effectively encrypt an e-mail from reading it .
It is also possible to conceal the metadata of an e-mail communication with a high technical effort , so that it is not easy to recognize who has communicated with whom .

Here we tried to see this in other species .
He also noted that in dogs , like humans , the right half of the brain is responsible for the left and vice versa , and that the two hemispheres played different roles in feelings .
To learn more about how dogs react to the side swelling of their fellow dogs , the researchers monitored the animals while these films were watching other dogs .

When the animals saw how an otherwise drunk-free dog moved the tail to the right ( seen from the perspective of the dog ) , they remained completely relaxed .
But if the tail was mainly left ( again from the dog ’ s perspective ) , their heart rate rose and they looked restless .
According to Professor Vallortigara , the dogs do not deliberately communicate with each other through these movements .
